title: Introduction to the user Interface Architecture
subtitle: Explore the foundational elements and hierarchical structure of Guidewire's UI framework.

blocks.scenario: Imagine you're a developer tasked with customizing a Guidewire application's user interface. You need to add a new field, rearrange existing elements, or even create a new screen. Without understanding the underlying UI architecture, these tasks can feel like navigating a maze blindfolded.
blocks.question: How do Guidewire applications structure their user interfaces, and what are the fundamental building blocks you'll interact with to make these changes?

objectives: Identify the core components of the Guidewire application UI framework, including PCF elements, widgets, and locations.
Distinguish between atomic, primary container, secondary container, and top-level container widgets.
Explain the purpose and typical use cases for Detail View Panels, List View Panels, and Input Sets.
Interpret the hierarchical structure of Guidewire UI elements.
Understand common PCF editor conventions for modifying UI layouts.
Outline the process for deploying UI changes in a Guidewire application.

blocks.priorKnowledge: You've likely interacted with various software applications, observing how their screens are laid out, how you navigate between different sections, and how data is displayed. Think about common UI patterns like forms, tables, and navigation menus.
blocks.warmupQuestion: What are some common ways user interfaces organize information to make it easy for you to find and interact with data?
blocks.hint: Consider how web pages or desktop applications group related fields or actions.

blocks.heading: Foundations of the Guidewire UI: PCF Elements, Widgets, and Locations
blocks.narrative:
The Guidewire application's user interface is built upon a robust, proprietary framework centered around the **Page Configuration Format (PCF)** object model. Think of a PCF as an XSD-validated XML document that meticulously describes the structure, layout, and behavior of every web UI element you see. While much of this definition occurs at the application level, some foundational aspects are managed at the platform level.

Within this framework, two conceptual representations are key: **Widgets** and **Locations**. A **widget** is essentially any PCF element that will be converted into HTML and displayed to the user. Not all widgets are visible; some act purely as containers, grouping other widgets into specific layouts. Widgets can also enforce permissions, ensuring that only authorized users can view or edit particular data. A **location**, on the other hand, is a PCF element that defines a navigable point within the application. It dictates how users (or the application itself) move from one area of the UI to another, often specifying which part of the browser window will update upon navigation and what permissions are required to access the data within that location. It's important to note that `<Widget />` or `<Location />` are conceptual; you won't find literal XML elements with these names.

The smallest building blocks of the Guidewire UI are **atomic widgets**. These are individual field items like input fields, display cells, or buttons. They are always defined within a larger container widget or a location, serving to display a single data value or execute a specific action. For instance, a text input for a name or a button to save changes would be atomic widgets.

Building upon atomic widgets, **container widgets** are designed to hold and organize other widgets. They can be defined in their own dedicated PCF files, promoting reusability, or nested as child containers within other PCF elements. The PCF object model's container-based nature simplifies UI development and modification, as the hierarchical structure makes it easier to locate and adjust visual elements. This modular approach allows for efficient organization of data and functionality into logical groups, making the UI both manageable and scalable.
keyPoints: Guidewire UI is built on the PCF (Page Configuration Format) object model, an XSD-validated XML document.
Widgets are displayable PCF elements converted to HTML, including visible elements and containers.
Locations are navigable PCF elements that define user movement and access permissions.
Atomic widgets are the smallest UI building blocks, displaying individual data or actions.
Container widgets group other widgets, organizing data and functionality hierarchically.

callouts.title: PCF (Page Configuration Format)
callouts.content: A proprietary, XSD-validated XML document that defines the structure, layout, and behavior of Guidewire web user interfaces.

callouts.title: Widget
callouts.content: A PCF element that is converted into HTML and displayed. Can be visible or a container for other widgets, and can specify user permissions.

callouts.title: Location
callouts.content: A PCF element that a user or the application can navigate to, defining how users move between UI areas and specifying required permissions.

blocks.heading: Primary Container Widgets: Detail Views, List Views, and Input Sets
blocks.narrative:
Moving up the hierarchy from atomic widgets, we encounter **primary container widgets**. These are foundational, reusable views specifically designed to organize atomic widgets into logical groups. They play a crucial role in presenting data effectively to the user.

One prominent type of primary container is the **Detail View Panel**. These panels are typically used to organize and manage a collection of related pieces of information that constitute a single record. Imagine viewing all the individual fields for a specific user, claim, or policy – that's a Detail View Panel's job. While they commonly display information from a single entity, they are flexible enough to present data from multiple, even unrelated, entities, or even calculated values. The best practice for Detail View Panels is to present all relevant detailed information for a particular interface, and nothing irrelevant, often focusing on fields of a specific entity and a few closely related ones. They typically use columns to organize atomic widgets effectively and can be referenced by screens and secondary views.

In contrast to Detail View Panels, **List View Panels** are designed to provide summary information for a collection of records. If a Detail View Panel shows you *all* the details of *one* person, a List View Panel shows you *key* details of *many* people in a table format. This allows users to quickly scan and understand information about multiple records simultaneously, such as a list of bank accounts or addresses.

Another important primary container is the **Input Set**. Input Sets are essentially groups of atomic widgets bundled together. Their primary benefit lies in their reusability and the ability to apply common visibility or editability conditions across multiple widgets within the set. For example, an input set for an address might include street, city, state, and zip code fields, all of which could be hidden or made editable based on a single condition. Input Sets can also be targeted for partial page updates, which helps improve UI performance by only refreshing specific sections of a screen. While they share attributes with primary containers by organizing atomic widgets, they must be embedded within Detail View Panels and cannot have toolbars directly associated with them.
keyPoints: Primary containers are reusable views that organize atomic widgets.
Detail View Panels focus on displaying comprehensive information for a single record, often using columns.
List View Panels display summary information for multiple records in a table format.
Input Sets group atomic widgets for reuse, applying common visibility/editability, and supporting partial page updates.

blocks.heading: Secondary and Top-Level Container Widgets: Cards, List Detail Panels, and Screens
blocks.narrative:
As we continue to explore the Guidewire UI hierarchy, we encounter **secondary container widgets**, which serve to organize collections of primary containers. These containers provide a higher level of organization, bringing together related views to enhance usability and streamline user workflows.

Examples of secondary containers include **Cards** and **List Detail Panels**. A Card is essentially a collection of other cards, with each card typically containing either Detail Views or List Views. This allows for a tabbed or multi-section layout where different primary views can be accessed easily. The **List Detail Panel** is another powerful secondary container. It combines a top List View with a bottom view panel. The bottom panel dynamically displays detailed data about the item currently selected in the top List View. This pattern is incredibly useful for scenarios where users need to browse a list of items and then immediately see the full details of a selected item without navigating to a new screen.

At the very top of the container hierarchy sits the **Screen**. The Screen is the ultimate top-level container, responsible for organizing all secondary and primary containers. Every atomic widget, primary view, and secondary view is ultimately contained, directly or indirectly, within a Screen. Screens are crucial because they connect the visual content displayed in the user interface with the application's navigation flow. They define the overall layout and content of a major application view, acting as the entry point for users to interact with specific functionalities or data sets. For instance, the "Person: William Andy Details" page you might see in a Guidewire application is an example of a Screen, encompassing various panels and widgets to present comprehensive information.
keyPoints: Secondary containers organize collections of primary containers.
Examples of secondary containers include Cards (collections of views) and List Detail Panels (list view with dynamic detail panel).
The Screen is the top-level container, organizing all secondary and primary containers.
Screens connect UI content with application navigation and serve as major application views.

blocks.heading: Comprehensive PCF Hierarchy and the Role of Locations
blocks.narrative:
To solidify our understanding, let's review the complete **container widget hierarchy**. At the lowest level, we have **atomic widgets**, which are the individual displayable elements. These atomic widgets can only be directly contained by **primary views**, such as Detail View Panels and List View Panels, whose purpose is to logically group these smaller elements.

Moving up, **secondary views** like Card View Panels and List Detail Panels are designed to organize these primary views. Importantly, secondary views generally cannot directly contain most atomic widgets; their role is to orchestrate collections of primary views. There's an interesting exception where a primary view can sometimes be placed within another primary view, a concept we'll delve into further in lessons on List Views. Additionally, a secondary view can even contain other secondary views, allowing for complex, nested UI structures. **Input Sets**, while organizing atomic widgets like primary views, are unique in that they cannot be directly referenced by secondary views or screens; they must be embedded within Detail View Panels.

Finally, at the apex of the hierarchy are **Screens**. These are the top-level containers, connecting the displayed UI content with the application's navigation. A Screen can directly contain both primary and secondary views, but typically not atomic widgets directly. Screens are referenced by **locations**, which are the PCF elements defining navigable points in the application.

**Locations** themselves do not define any visual content; instead, they contain Screens that do. A location is a PCF element that a user or the application can navigate to, specifying which part of the browser window will be updated and what permissions are required. This separation of navigation logic from visual content allows for flexible and secure control over user access and application flow. In essence, the entire **PCF hierarchy** is a structured way to define both the visual presentation (widgets) and the navigational pathways (locations) within a Guidewire application, ensuring a consistent and manageable user experience.
keyPoints: The PCF hierarchy flows from atomic widgets to primary views, then to secondary views, and finally to Screens.
Atomic widgets are contained by primary views (Detail View Panels, List View Panels).
Secondary views (Card View Panels, List Detail Panels) organize primary views.
Screens are top-level containers, organizing primary and secondary views, and are referenced by locations.
Locations define navigation points and access control, containing screens but not defining visual content themselves.

blocks.heading: Applying UI Architecture: A User Story for Customization
blocks.narrative:
Now that we've explored the theoretical foundations of the Guidewire UI architecture, let's consider a practical application. In real-world Guidewire projects, business analysts often provide **user stories** that describe desired changes or new features for the application's user interface. These stories translate directly into tasks for developers to modify existing PCF files or create new ones.

For instance, imagine a scenario where an insurance company has reviewed the out-of-the-box (OOTB) UI layout for the "Details" screen's "Person Info" tab. They might identify a need for minor adjustments to improve usability or align with internal data presentation standards. The user story could specify requirements such as reordering existing widgets – for example, moving the "Date of Birth" widget to appear below the "Marital Status" widget. Another common request might be to add visual separators, like a horizontal divider, to logically group related fields and enhance readability, perhaps between the "Tax Filing Status" and "Gender" fields.

These types of modifications are fundamental tasks for Guidewire developers. They involve navigating the PCF file structure, identifying the relevant container widgets, and then using Guidewire Studio's PCF editor to implement the changes. Understanding the widget hierarchy and the purpose of different container types becomes critical here, as it guides you to the correct location within the XML structure to make your adjustments. This user story serves as an excellent lead-in to our demonstration, where we'll see exactly how such requirements are translated into actual UI changes within the Guidewire application.
keyPoints: User stories drive UI customization in Guidewire projects.
Common UI modifications include reordering widgets and adding visual separators.
Implementing changes requires navigating PCF files and using Guidewire Studio's PCF editor.
Understanding the widget hierarchy is crucial for effective UI modification.

blocks.question:
Define the broad purpose for each element category:
o A) Atomic widgets
B) Container widgets
C) Locations
blocks.referenceAnswer:
The correct responses are:
A) Atomic widgets display individual elements of data and/or functionality.
B) Container widgets group atomic widgets into logical groups.
C) Locations define how users move from one place in the application to the next.

blocks.question: What does a PCF file define?
blocks.referenceAnswer: APCF file defines a container widget or location and its contents.

blocks.question:
What does each PCF editor convention mean?
o A) Acontainer widget shaded light blue
B) Alight green line
C) Ared background
blocks.referenceAnswer:
A) The container widget is referenced by the current PCF file and Its contents are
contained in another file
B) For the currently selected widget tool, a new widget of that type will be placed in
the current location.
C) The PCF file has an error in it.

blocks.question: Howdo you deploy PCF changes?
blocks.referenceAnswer:
You can restart the server. Restarting the server reloads PCF files at startup. A more
efficient approach for development is to Reload the PCF files. With internal tools
enabled, you can use the ALT+SHIFT+L keystroke to reload the PCF files. You can
also log in with an administrator user account and reload PCF files from the Internal
Tools Reload page.

keyTakeaways: Guidewire UI is built on an XML-based PCF object model, defining structure, layout, and behavior.
UI elements are categorized into Atomic Widgets (individual fields/actions), Container Widgets (grouping other widgets), and Locations (navigation points).
Container widgets follow a hierarchy: Primary (Detail View, List View, Input Set) -> Secondary (Card, List Detail Panel) -> Top-level (Screen).
Locations define how users navigate the application and control access, containing screens but not visual content.
Guidewire Studio and developer shortcuts (Alt+Shift+W/I/E) are essential tools for UI development and inspection.
PCF changes can be deployed by restarting the server or more efficiently by reloading PCF files via internal tools.
blocks.realWorldConnection: Understanding this architecture is crucial for any Guidewire developer. It allows you to efficiently customize screens, implement new business logic, and troubleshoot UI issues, ensuring the application meets specific user and business needs. Mastering PCF development is a core skill for tailoring Guidewire solutions.
